docTitle.titlePart: Production of fully human antibodies by transgenic mice

front.div:
The ability to produce a diverse repertoire of fully human monoclonal
antibodies may have significant applications to human therapy. One of
the most promising approaches to the production of therapeutic human
monoclonal antibodies is the creation of a mouse strain engineered to produce
a large repertoire of human antibodies in the absence of mouse antibodies.
Recently, such mice have been generated by introducing segments of human
immunoglobulin loci into the germlines of mice deficient in mouse antibody
production as a result of gene targeting. These mice produce significant
levels of fully human antibodies with a diverse adult-like repertoire and,
upon immunization with antigens, generate antigen-specific fully human
monoclonal antibodies. Such strains of mice may provide the optimal source
for producing human monoclonal antibodies with high affinity and specificity
against a broad spectrum of antigens, including human antigens.
